meaning_mnemonic: Something that <kanji>obstruct</kanji>s and also does <kanji>damage</kanji> is an <vocabulary>obstruction</vocabulary>. No obstruction is ever good and if left too long it really will cause damage and <vocabulary>interference</vocabulary> as well.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>illuminate</kanji>, so this means <vocabulary>to illuminate</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to shine light on</vocabulary> something.

But don't get it confused with 照れる, which is "to feel embarrassed" — that would be embarrassing. You know this is "to illuminate" because you get a <reading>rash</reading> (らす) every time something shines on you too much.
An <kanji>aviation</kanji> (航空) <kanji>ticket</kanji> is the kind of ticket you need to fly on an airplane. That's an <vocabulary>airplane ticket</vocabulary>.
詰まる is "to be stuffed." So, if your <kanji>nose</kanji> is <kanji>stuffed</kanji>, then you have a <vocabulary>stuffy nose</vocabulary>.

詰める is "to stuff in." If you're really stuffing in your thoughts (<kanji>think</kanji>), you're thinking very deeply and seriously. So this is <vocabulary>to brood</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to dwell on</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to take something to heart</vocabulary>.

思い詰める suggests you're pondering deeply over something serious or distressing, bordering on overthinking.

When you really <kanji>stuff in</kanji> (詰める) what you are <kanji>see</kanji>ing, you're really looking at something, causing you <vocabulary>to stare at</vocabulary> whatever it is you're stuffing your seeing into.

A <kanji>male</kanji> <kanji>dog</kanji> is a <vocabulary>male dog</vocabulary>.

It's worth mentioning that you'll see this most often written in katakana, as both オス犬 and オスの犬.

auxiliary_meanings.meaning: To Let Something Come To An End

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 絶える means "to die out?" Well 絶やす is its transitive version, meaning <vocabulary>to let something die out</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to put an end to something</vocabulary>. 

絶やす is used when you stop something from continuing, like ending a family line, letting a tradition fade, or allowing a fire to go out. You know this because if you're putting an end to something, you probably don't like it, so you say "<reading>YAASS</reading>" (やす) with a big evil grin as you let it die out.

Note that 絶やす often appears in its negative form 絶やさない, because it's commonly used to describe the intent not to let something precious or important come to an end.

meanings.meaning: To Put An End To Something

meaning_mnemonic:
緊張 means "nervousness" or "tension." So, the verb version is <vocabulary>to feel nervous</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to get tense</vocabulary>.

People often use 緊張する when they're about to do something important, like giving a speech or taking a test. In formal contexts it can also be used to talk about muscles physically getting tense.

<kanji>Dissolve</kanji> and then <kanji>join</kanji> together again to create a reaction, a <vocabulary>fusion</vocabulary> reaction.

融合 is a relatively formal word that describes two or more things blending together to become a unified whole. It can describe fusion in the scientific sense (like nuclear fusion) or in a more figurative sense, such as the fusion of ideas, cultures, styles, or technologies.

Someone <kanji>dissolve</kanji>s their <kanji>resources</kanji> in order to more easily give them to you, because they are <vocabulary>financing</vocabulary> you with a <vocabulary>loan</vocabulary>. This someone is an investor, and they want to see your business succeed!

融資 is a formal word for <vocabulary>lending money</vocabulary>. It's used when a financial institution lends money to an individual or a business to help with things like starting a company, buying property, or handling expenses.

Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>detach</kanji>, but what happens when something detaches? It causes it <vocabulary>to become separated</vocabulary>, aka <vocabulary>to separate</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to move away</vocabulary> from something else.

You use 離れる when two things that were together separate and become distant from one another. This can refer to a physical detachment, but it can also describe someone moving away from a place, group, or role, or even people drifting apart emotionally. You also use it to describe places that are far from each other.
<kanji>Detach</kanji> from your <kanji>marriage</kanji>. This is a <vocabulary>divorce</vocabulary>.

When you <kanji>divide</kanji> and <kanji>detach</kanji> things from each other, you're creating <vocabulary>separation</vocabulary> between them. Makes sense, right?

分離 is a word you might hear in science when discussing how different substances, like oil and water, don't mix and separate from each other.

Additionally, 分離 can also be a formal term used to describe separating groups of people, often in discussions about serious topics like social <vocabulary>segregation</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>seal</kanji> that's <kanji>model</kanji>ed after you is a useful <vocabulary>seal</vocabulary> indeed — it's your very own <vocabulary>personal seal</vocabulary>!

印鑑 is a small stamp with your name carved into it. In Japan, people use it on official documents instead of signing their name. It's like your legally recognized "signature stamp," and it's something most adults in Japan need to have.
壊す is "to break something." 壊れる is when something just gets broken or is broken, and you're not doing the breaking. This is <vocabulary>to be broken</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>thing</kanji> that could <kanji>break</kanji> easily, is a <vocabulary>fragile thing</vocabulary>. Be careful with things like this.

Something that <kanji>previously</kanji> happened has <vocabulary>already</vocabulary> happened.

既に is relatively formal. Use it as a neutral way to describe actions or states that are already complete. By comparison, もう is more casual and might sometimes carry a sense of surprise or regret that something has happened sooner than expected.

Something that <kanji>previously</kanji> <kanji>exist</kanji>ed is probably still <vocabulary>existing</vocabulary> now.

既存 is a relatively formal word that is often used in official contexts to talk about things that are already in place, like existing systems, facilities, or ideas.

It was <kanji>previously</kanji> <kanji>decide</kanji>d, which means it's been <vocabulary>decided</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>settled</vocabulary>.

既決 is a formal word that means something has already been decided or settled. You'll come across it in official settings, like when a company meeting wraps up and certain topics are marked as 既決.
You <kanji>pass through</kanji> like completely <kanji>normal</kanji>. You are <vocabulary>normal</vocabulary>. You do things <vocabulary>normally</vocabulary>, normally.

The <kanji>normal</kanji> <kanji>steps</kanji> are the ones that are totally <vocabulary>usual</vocabulary>. They're the ones you <vocabulary>usually</vocabulary> do, unlike those weird not usual steps.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>knit</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to knit</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Knit</kanji> and <kanji>gather</kanji> everything back together, which you knit. When you do this to fix things and bring it back together, this is an <vocabulary>edit</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>knit</kanji> <kanji>someone</kanji> is one who knits words together and makes them better. This someone is an <vocabulary>editor</vocabulary>.

An <kanji>outside</kanji> <kanji>task</kanji>s <kanji>minister</kanji> (大臣) is someone who is tasked with dealing with things that are outside the country. This is the <vocabulary>minister of foreign affairs</vocabulary>.

The kanji means <kanji>showy</kanji>, and this word is basically a super positive version of that — it means <vocabulary>bright and showy</vocabulary>. 

華やか describes the kind of elegant beauty that brightens a room. A little showy, maybe, but in an uplifting way rather than just gaudy. It can describe <vocabulary>gorgeous</vocabulary> clothes, like 華やかなドレス (a gorgeous dress) or bright, <vocabulary>festive</vocabulary> colors and atmospheres.
中国 is China, right? That's what this 中 represents. And, of course the Chinese are known for being super showy, which is why you have <kanji>showy</kanji> there.

You're "underground" (地下) in the <kanji>streets</kanji>, but don't worry, you're not in some post-apocalyptic sci-fi novel — most of the underground streets and areas in Japan are just <vocabulary>underground shopping mall</vocabulary>s.

地下街, or <vocabulary>underground shopping center</vocabulary>s, are common in big cities in Japan, especially near train stations, where you'll find lots of shops, restaurants, and walkways below street level.
Oh wow, that is <kanji>exceptional</kanji>ly <kanji>showy</kanji>! Whatever that thing is, it is <vocabulary>luxurious</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>splendid</vocabulary> and I want one.

When a <kanji>model</kanji> human <kanji>determine</kanji>s something, that's an <vocabulary>appraisal</vocabulary> you should probably pay attention to. This isn't just some random nobody off the street — they're a model determiner, so they're really giving you an <vocabulary>expert judgment</vocabulary>.

鑑定 often refers to evaluating the authenticity or value of things like art, antiques, or real estate. It's also used in contexts like fingerprint analysis, or in legal settings where court-appointed experts provide technical evaluations to help judges make decisions.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>exclude</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to exclude</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Sweep</kanji> and <kanji>exclude</kanji> all that dirt from the floor, please. When you do this a lot, it becomes <vocabulary>cleaning</vocabulary>.

掃除 is a common word you'll hear often in daily life, and it can mean anything from quickly vacuuming your room to doing a full-on deep clean of your entire house.
<kanji>Exclude</kanji> this one and put it <kanji>outside</kanji> what we're considering. This is the <vocabulary>exception</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>inquire</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to inquire</vocabulary>, or simply <vocabulary>to ask</vocabulary>.

尋ねる is the polite, slightly formal word you use when you directly ask someone for information you don't know — like directions or details.

When you <kanji>inquire</kanji> about a <kanji>problem</kanji>, you tend to do <vocabulary>interrogation</vocabulary>-style <vocabulary>questioning</vocabulary> to get to the bottom of it. Why is it like this? What happened? Is it bigger than a breadbox?

This has the same meaning as the kanji, specifically the <vocabulary>how much</vocabulary> meaning. To remember this, just think about how <reading>Ra</reading>, the Egyptian God, is always asking "<vocabulary>How much</vocabulary> will it cost to build this pyramid?" Ugh, too much, let's hire some slaves.

This has the same meaning as the kanji, specifically the <vocabulary>how many</vocabulary> meaning. You know this because you ask "how many" and they answer "つ." This can also be used to ask <vocabulary>how old</vocabulary> someone is, but generally only for children's ages.

This word is usually written in kana in modern writing.

<kanji>How many</kanji>? <kanji>What</kanji>? In this area of <kanji>study</kanji>, you ask these questions a lot. This area of study is <vocabulary>geometry</vocabulary>, because you have to ask how many sides and how much the area is or something (can you tell I don't remember any maths?).
A <kanji>corridor</kanji> is <kanji>below</kanji>. What do you call a corridor that's below? Well, really it's still just a <vocabulary>corridor</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>hallway</vocabulary>.

An <kanji>image</kanji> <kanji>corridor</kanji> is a corridor in which there are images hanging on the wall. This is a <vocabulary>picture gallery</vocabulary>.

Note that 画廊 generally refers to a physical <vocabulary>art gallery</vocabulary>, where artworks are exhibited for in-person viewing.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>sweep</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to sweep</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
<kanji>Mud</kanji> <kanji>water</kanji> is <vocabulary>muddy water</vocabulary>. Don't step in it, if you can help it.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

棒 refers to anything that's long, thin, and solid, whether it's a <vocabulary>pole</vocabulary>, a <vocabulary>rod</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>stick</vocabulary>. It can be used for a wide variety of objects, from tree branches to popsicle sticks.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>surprised</kanji>, so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be surprised</vocabulary>.

I'm so <kanji>surprised</kanji> that it caused me to <kanji>sigh</kanji>. This is like when you see something super impressive and it surprises the heck out of you. Then, you breathe out a sigh because of your great <vocabulary>amazement</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>admiration</vocabulary> for what you just saw.

驚嘆 is a formal word you'll mostly see in writing to describe something truly awe-inspiring, or the state of being amazed by an impressive thing. It's about more than just surprise — it describes the deep admiration you feel when marveling at great talent, skill, or beauty.
When you <kanji>sigh</kanji>, you feel a certain type of emotion. A type that makes you feel sad and causes you <vocabulary>to lament</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to grieve</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>sigh</kanji> <kanji>breath</kanji> is a <vocabulary>sigh</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>feeling</kanji> where you <kanji>sigh</kanji> is one in which you're surprised by something, and can't believe it, so you sigh. Ugh, *sigh*. What <kanji>token</kanji> represents this in writing? An <vocabulary>exclamation mark</vocabulary>!!!!

A <kanji>storage</kanji> <kanji>warehouse</kanji> is some kind of <vocabulary>warehouse</vocabulary>, or some kind of <vocabulary>storehouse</vocabulary>.

Curious about the difference between 倉庫 and 庫? While 庫 refers to traditional Japanese storehouses, 倉庫 is used for modern warehouses and storehouses (both the commercial and personal kind).

The kanji means <kanji>storehouse</kanji>, and the vocab is also <vocabulary>storehouse</vocabulary>!

Wondering what the difference between 倉 and 庫 is? Long ago, 倉 were places to store grain, while 庫 used to be associated with places to store vehicles, as the kanji composition suggests. These days, they're both used for general storage, but also refer to places to store goods and merchandise. Between the two, 倉 is much more commonly used.
A <kanji>child</kanji> who is the <kanji>grandchild</kanji> of someone else is a <vocabulary>descendant</vocabulary> of that person.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

巣 refers to all kinds of animal homes — a bird's <vocabulary>nest</vocabulary>, a spider's web, a mouse's burrow, or even a beehive. Sometimes, it can be used figuratively to describe places where people hole up, whether that be a cozy home for lovers or a shady hideout for gangs…

When you live in a nest (巣), there's only one reason for you to stand up (立つ), and that's to <vocabulary>leave the nest</vocabulary>. Your mother may be sad about this, but everyone needs to <vocabulary>become independent</vocabulary> someday.
ハチ is a bee. Buzz buzz. Just imagine "eight bees" combining into one bee, making it a "hachi." Then, there's a <kanji>nest</kanji>. What is a nest for bees? A <vocabulary>beehive</vocabulary>.
クモ is a spider. Add a <kanji>nest</kanji> to it, and you have a spider nest. What do spiders call their nests? They call it a <vocabulary>spiderweb</vocabulary> (that is, if they can talk).

The kanji and the word are the same, except that this isn't just any type of <kanji>belt</kanji>. It's an <vocabulary>obi</vocabulary>, a wide cloth <vocabulary>belt</vocabulary> worn with traditional clothes like kimono and yukata.

This <kanji>earth</kanji> <kanji>belt</kanji> is the area within the belt, which holds this area of earth in. It is separate from the rest of the earth, making it its own <vocabulary>zone</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>district</vocabulary>.

Draw a <kanji>straight</kanji> line across the <kanji>diameter</kanji> of a circle, then measure it. This gives you the <vocabulary>diameter</vocabulary>. Whoa, look out everyone — we've got a geometry whiz in the room!
<kanji>Half</kanji> a <kanji>diameter</kanji> is a <vocabulary>radius</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Rescue</kanji> in a <kanji>hurry</kanji> using this <kanji>car</kanji>. What kinds of cars can do this? How about an <vocabulary>ambulance</vocabulary>.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>rescue</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to rescue</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>scatter</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be scattered</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to get scattered</vocabulary>. 

散る is an intransitive verb, meaning something is scattering on its own. It's commonly used to describe when things like petals or leaves fall, fluttering down and scattering across the ground. It can also be used more abstractly, such as a crowd suddenly dispersing, your concentration breaking, your dreams falling apart, or even a soldier "falling" in battle.

You know 散る is intransitive because you rue (る) your decision not to go see the cherry blossoms when they were in bloom; now the petals have all scattered to the wind and you've missed your chance. Darn.
<kanji>Scatter</kanji> around the ground and <kanji>walk</kanji>. When you walk in a scatter all around, you're going for <vocabulary>a walk</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>a stroll</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Untie</kanji> and <kanji>scatter</kanji> everything. This will cause the <vocabulary>dissolution</vocabulary> the <vocabulary>breakup</vocabulary>, and indeed the <vocabulary>breaking up</vocabulary> of whatever is being untied then scattered.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Can also mean <vocabulary>flour</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Wheat</kanji> <kanji>powder</kanji> is <vocabulary>wheat flour</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>flower</kanji> <kanji>powder</kanji> <kanji>symptom</kanji>s are when you start sneezing from flower powder, aka pollen that comes from all sorts of flowers, which is pretty much all plants. This word, however, refers to the most common version of this sickness, which is <vocabulary>hay fever</vocabulary>.

Something that is in a <kanji>powder</kanji> <kanji>condition</kanji> is something that has been <vocabulary>powdered</vocabulary>. Puff!

粉状 is a relatively formal word that is used to describe something being in powder form.
A <kanji>mountain</kanji> <kanji>vein</kanji> is a vein that extends across the land, and is covered in mountains. This refers to a <vocabulary>mountain range</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>field</kanji> <kanji>vegetable</kanji> is still a <vocabulary>vegetable</vocabulary>, whether it comes from the field or not.
If you eat <kanji>vegetable</kanji> <kanji>food</kanji> you are on a <vocabulary>vegetarian diet</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Freight</kanji> <kanji>thing</kanji>s is <vocabulary>freight</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>cargo</vocabulary>.

The thing that will <kanji>pass through</kanji> <kanji>freight</kanji> is <vocabulary>currency</vocabulary>. Why? Because when you want freight to be your own, you have to put money through it and to the person who owns it. When you do that, it becomes yours. Use that currency!
A <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>land</kanji> is the biggest types of land on this earth that there are. That is a <vocabulary>continent</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>land</kanji> <kanji>army</kanji> is the <vocabulary>land army</vocabulary>, also known as the plain old <vocabulary>army</vocabulary>.

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>resemble</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to resemble</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to look like</vocabulary>.

Something that's <kanji>flat</kanji> and <kanji>equal</kanji> to everything around it, all those flat things around it, are <vocabulary>average</vocabulary>. They're the <vocabulary>mean</vocabulary> (same as average).

This is <kanji>equal</kanji> and that is <kanji>equal</kanji>. They're both the same, amazing! They carry <vocabulary>equality</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>uniformity</vocabulary>,  and <vocabulary>evenness</vocabulary>.
Things are <kanji>equal</kanji> in how they're <kanji>arrange</kanji>d. They have perfect <vocabulary>symmetry</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>balance</vocabulary>.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

墓 means <vocabulary>grave</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>tomb</vocabulary>. Since you want to be respectful when talking about someone's eternal resting place, it's common to add the honorific お and say お墓.

A <kanji>grave</kanji> <kanji>ground</kanji> is an area with lots of graves in the ground. This is a <vocabulary>cemetery</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>graveyard</vocabulary>.

墓地 is the standard word for a designated and organized cemetery.

Did you know that the <kanji>mountain</kanji> that is <kanji>rich</kanji> in <kanji>samurai</kanji> happens to be Japan's most famous mountain? It makes sense considering samurai are probably Japan's most famous thing as well. Combine the two most famous things and you have <vocabulary>Mt Fuji</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>Mount Fuji</vocabulary> if you'd rather write it that way).

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>rich</kanji> so the verb vocab version would be <vocabulary>to be rich in</vocabulary>.

富む is a formal word that's commonly used in writing. While it can refer to material wealth, it's more commonly used figuratively to describe an abundance of a certain quality, a place rich in nature or specific resources, or emotional richness or fulfillment.
The kanji and the word are almost exactly the same. Someone who is <kanji>rich</kanji> has <vocabulary>wealth</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>riches</vocabulary>, right?
If you're <kanji>rich</kanji> and <kanji>abundant</kanji>, you are super <vocabulary>wealthy</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>affluent</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>rich</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>way</kanji> of <kanji>virtue</kanji> is the way you take if you have <vocabulary>morals</vocabulary>. Hopefully you have some.

This is one of those words that makes more sense when you look at the reading. The "Virtue River" isn't some virtuous river, it's in fact the <vocabulary>Tokugawa</vocabulary> family name, made famous by the Tokugawa shogunate. They ran Japan for a while, you know?

The <kanji>virtue</kanji> <kanji>island</kanji> <kanji>prefecture</kanji> is <vocabulary>Tokushima prefecture</vocabulary>. The reading will give away the meaning of this one, so long as you knew "prefecture."

Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>look for</kanji> and the verb version of the kanji is <vocabulary>to look for</vocabulary>.


Curious about the difference between 捜す and 探す? While there is some overlap between the two, 捜す is typically used in official, thorough searches for something or someone that is thought to concretely exist and has disappeared or cannot be easily found. In contrast, 探す can also be used for personal searches for things that one desires or is looking for.
<kanji>Look for</kanji> something. <kanji>Research</kanji> answers. This is an <vocabulary>academic inquiry</vocabulary>, or in other words, <vocabulary>research</vocabulary>.
You <kanji>look for</kanji> things and you <kanji>spy</kanji> on people. Your job isn't as glamorous as it sounds. You're a <vocabulary>private detective</vocabulary>.

When you go <kanji>inside</kanji> somewhere to quietly <kanji>spy</kanji> on someone, you're doing a <vocabulary>secret investigation</vocabulary>.

内偵 is a formal word for investigations where the target doesn't know they're being investigated. It can mean an <vocabulary>undercover investigation</vocabulary> by police, or it can be a secret check on a business partner, a new hire, or even a suspicious spouse by companies or detectives.
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>fear</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to fear</vocabulary>.

You learned 迷う means "to go astray," and 迷わす is its transitive version, meaning it takes a direct object. So it means <vocabulary>to lead someone astray</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to perplex someone</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to mislead someone</vocabulary>.

While 迷わす can mean literally causing someone to get lost, it's more commonly used for the act of confusing someone — for example, overwhelming them with difficult choices or intentionally misleading them in a malicious way.

You know this verb is transitive because there's nothing <reading>worse</reading> (わす) than purposefully misleading someone. Intentionally leading someone astray is worse than anything!

You learned that 積もる (to accumulate) is used when something like snow or dust piles up over time. 積む is the transitive version, so it means <vocabulary>to pile something up</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to stack up</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to load</vocabulary>. You know this because you are the one <reading>mo</reading>ving (む) things to pile them up!

積む is often used for physical actions like stacking boxes or loading luggage, but it's also used in more abstract ways, such as building up experience or skills. Think of it like "stacking up" experience points to level up in your life!

If 主催 means "host" or "hosting," the verb version of that would be <vocabulary>to host</vocabulary>.

主催する refers to hosting events, especially formal ones like conferences, concerts, or company parties. It's not just about "doing" an event — it shows that the person or group is the main sponsor and organizer, the one really in charge of making it happen.
If 催促 is <kanji>urge</kanji>, then the verb version would be <vocabulary>to urge</vocabulary>.

<kanji>How many</kanji> <kanji>occurence</kanji>s is just another way of asking <vocabulary>how many times</vocabulary>.

This word is more literary and formal than 何回 or 何度.
The kanji in this word means fear, but the word itself means probably. I guess you only have to fear something if it's probably going to happen, you know?
This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>fear</kanji>, so it means <vocabulary>fear</vocabulary> too.

"<kanji>Use</kanji> your <kanji>heart</kanji> and this <kanji>pole</kanji> when you guard me," you tell your <vocabulary>bodyguard</vocabulary>. A good bodyguard needs both — the heart of a lion, and a nice sturdy pole to smack fools with.

用心 actually means "caution," so 用心棒 suggests someone who watches out for danger — often with a 棒 (stick) in hand! The word has a bit of an old-school, samurai-era feel, but it still gets used both in writing and conversation from time to time.

The <kanji>flower</kanji> <kanji>way</kanji> (or the way of the flower) is the Japanese art of <vocabulary>flower arrangement</vocabulary>.

With such a lofty name, you know this isn't referring to any old flower arrangement you can buy in a shop. This is for the art and practice of <vocabulary>Japanese flower arrangement</vocabulary>, also known as ikebana.

If something has <kanji>showy</kanji> <kanji>beauty</kanji> then it's going a little overboard and is going to come across as <vocabulary>gaudy</vocabulary> <vocabulary>ostentation</vocabulary>. Too much is too much.

Compared to the similar word 派手 (flashy), 華美 suggests a more refined kind of <vocabulary>splendor</vocabulary> — luxurious and elegant, but a tad excessive. It's a formal word, generally used in writing to describe clothing or decor that's beautiful but verges on being showy.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

This is an intransitive verb, meaning that it happens on its own, and we're not talking about what makes it happen. So this verb means <vocabulary>to be extended</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to be delayed</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to be prolonged</vocabulary>. If you know the word ビル, you can think about how building work is always prolonged or delayed, to help you remember that this is intransitive. We never know why it's delayed, it just happens all by itself!

You learned that 我が means "our", so our <kanji>country</kanji> is simply <vocabulary>our country</vocabulary>.

Just like 我が itself, this expression is somewhat old-fashioned and stylized. It comes up a lot in political discourse and other formal contexts.

The kanji means male and this also means male. It's mostly used for animals.

Note that this is often written in katakana, as オス.
Something that's <kanji>plentiful</kanji> and <kanji>rich</kanji> is <vocabulary>abundant</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>plentiful</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>rich</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>savings</kanji>, so the verb vocab version means <vocabulary>to save up</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to store</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to accumulate</vocabulary> something valuable.

貯める is used when you're saving up something useful over time — typically money, loyalty points, or airline miles, for example, but sometimes water and other resources too.
